text: Hi, my name is Milind Pathak

and I am a solutions architect
 on the SAP team here at AWS.

Customers depend on
 their SAP applications

to support their mission-
 critical lines of business.

For this reason,
 customers tell us that they want ways

to migrate SAP applications to AWS
 with minimal downtime.

Today, I’m going to walk you through
 how to do just that using CloudEndure

migration for a single
 SAP HANA database server.
It enables you to quickly rehost

a large number of virtual machines
 on Amazon EC2 instances.

The first step is to register
 for a CloudEndure migration account

which is free
 for AWS customers.
Once registered and logged in,

you need to confirm your business
 email ID to activate your account.

After this step, you are ready
 to create a new project.

Begin by giving it a project name,
 selecting a project type

and then create
 your migration project.
Once your project is set up,

you will need to enter
 your AWS credentials.

After this, you can configure
 replication settings like the source

and target as well as additional
 settings like server type,

subnet, security group, EBS volume
 type, network configuration etc.
You can also encrypt the volumes,

attach tags
 to the staging area resources,

restrict the bandwidth
 and update notification types.

After you create a project,
 you can install the CloudEndure agent
on your source servers.

You can grab the installation command
 from the CloudEndure console from

‘How to Add Machine Tab’ and run
 this command on the source servers.

The command downloads
 the CloudEndure agent
and starts the installation.

In this demo, I have an SAP
 HANA Linux

host with SAP HANA database installed
 and running on it.

Here you can identify and
 select disks you want to replicate.

You can also exclude certain
 disks from replication.

Once the installer identifies
 the disks it needs to replicate,

it starts downloading the CloudEndure
 agent from the CloudEndure servers.

These servers should be able
 to connect

to CloudEndure
 servers on port 443.
After the agent is installed,

the source server is visible
 in the CloudEndure console.
Going back to the machine tab,

you can see here the machine has been
 registered into CloudEndure console.

It will do some preparations like
 creating security groups and rules.

Once that has done, it will start
 the data replication process as well.

At this point, you can update
 the server blueprint

and modify any specific
 settings for replication.
You can look at the security groups,

designate an IP address,
 use an existing ENI

and which IAM role you will use
 when you launch this.

You can also see the replication
 settings

that you provided
 when you created the project

and you can change them here
 if you want.
Under the source tab,

you will see all of the disks
 are just going to replicate.

CloudEndure will automatically start
 creating the stage area resources
and then start the replication.

You can see the progress
 of replication in the status bar.

You will now have to wait
 until initial data sync is complete.

If you want to perform some tasks
 when you launch a new EC2 instance,

you will create
 both launch scripts.

These can be shell scripts
 able to complete an area of tasks
like creating DNS entries,

creating empty file systems
 that are not replicated,

changing IP addresses
 or any other custom
tasks to be done after cut over.

Now let’s check back
 on our replication process.

You can see here that the data
 replication is completed

and now you can perform
 a test cut over.

This allows you to perform
 no impact mock cut overs

while your source system
 is still in sync with the data,
in the VPC staging area.
You can see the job in process.

You can check for the updates
 in the logs.

You can see that within ten minutes
 it has launched a new EC2 instance.

Once you login, you can see
 your system has been preserved
and copied as is.

After you have performed validation
 to your satisfaction

you wait for your migration
 cut over window.

When it is time, you can cut
 over your SAP systems into AWS.

Perform the validation
 from the new server.

Perform post-processing
 and then release the new
SAP HANA database to your users.

CloudEndure also provide APIs
 to automate the migration process.

You can use CloudEndure
 Migration Factory

to migrate hundreds of servers
 at the same time

and that is how you migrate
 SAP applications and databases to AWS

with minimal downtime
 using AWS CloudEndure Migration.
Thank you for watching.
